initial_story:
Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever taking place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

On Thursday, the court heard from several witnesses who testified about their interactions with Daniels and her former lawyer Michael Avenatti. 

One of those witnesses was David Pecker, the former CEO of American Media Inc., which published the National Enquirer. Pecker testified that he had met with Daniels' former lawyer Michael Avenatti in late 2018 to discuss a potential story about Daniels' alleged affair with Trump. He said Avenatti wanted the company to pay Daniels $1 million for her silence on the matter. Pecker said he turned down the offer.

Another witness was Keith Davidson, Daniels' former lawyer who represented her during her negotiations with American Media Inc. over the alleged affair. Davidson testified that he had been pressured by Avenatti to sign a nondisclosure agreement (NDA) with Daniels that would have prevented her from speaking publicly about the affair. He said Avenatti threatened to release information about Davidson's own alleged sexual misconduct if he didn't cooperate.

The final witness was Julie Swetnick, who claimed in a sworn affidavit that she had seen Trump and other men engage in sexual misconduct at parties in the 1980s and 1990s. Swetnick testified that she had only recently come forward with her allegations because she had been afraid of retaliation.

In response to the testimony, Daniels took the stand to refute many of the claims made by Pecker and Davidson. She denied that she had ever been paid to stay silent about the alleged affair and said she had only signed the NDA because she felt threatened by Avenatti.

The court adjourned until Friday, when it is expected that Avenatti will take the stand to give his own testimony.
